class_notes:
This Foundational Course prepares students for upper-level course work in the department by focusing on literacy about Hispanic cultures and developing critical thinking skills in Spanish. 
With the intention of improving these two skills, students read and write about the histories, geographies, values, and artistic and cultural productions of the Hispanic world. The course fulfills a Continuing Communication requirement and as such will incorporate assignments that focus on multimodal communication across different genres. Ultimately, this course helps students develop skills related to the following three learning outcomes of the major or minor in Spanish:
1.	Apply fundamental critical reading skills to the analysis and interpretation of a variety of styles and genres from a range of texts in Spanish, such as film, political discourse, online media, essays, novels, and journalistic writing;
2.	Produce written communications in academic Spanish;
3.	Use spoken Spanish in an academic setting in formal communicative modes, such as presentational, interpretative, interpersonal.


TEXTS: Fuentes, Carlos. El espejo enterrado: reflexiones sobre España y América. Mexico, 
D.F.: Alfaguara/Penguin Random House Grupo Editorial, 2016. Available online through Emory Libraries after login with Emory credentials.
PARTICULARS: A Foundational Course that counts towards the major or minor in Spanish. Evaluation is based on class participation, written homework, exams, class presentations and attendance at or participation in events related to Hispanic cultures. Communication is integral to the course and students will engage in peer revisions and a process of reflection across assignments.
PREREQUISITE: Spanish 212 or official placement into our Foundational Course level (courses numbered 300-318). If you haven't taken our placement exam yet, please visit https://spanport.emory.edu/undergraduate/placement/spanish-placement.html.
